awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Bioinspired Catalysts with Earth-Abundant Metals for Reductive Treatment of Waterborne Contaminants
awd_abstract_narration:
A collaborative team of researchers will develop a novel class of catalysts inspired by nature. These “bioinspired catalysts” will be designed for the destruction of toxic waterborne oxyanion pollutants including perchlorate, nitrate, and bromate. Oxyanions are detected worldwide in surface water, groundwater, tapwater, and wastewater. These compounds represent a substantial risk to water supplies because they are highly mobile and toxic at low concentrations. Conventional oxyanion removal technologies include selective ion exchange, reverse osmosis, and biological reduction. However, these approaches face numerous drawbacks including the disposal of secondary waste and low treatment efficiency. The catalysts will use common molybdenum (Mo) and tungsten (W) metals and novel carbon and silica-based support materials in their construction. These wil result in significantly improved reactivity and stability compared to the currently used catalysts. Successful development of effective and inexpensive catalysts will decrease the associated economic and social burdens of removing oxyanions from water. These catalysts also hold promise in the development of a new generation of bioinspired Mo/W-based materials for environmental and energy-related fields. Additional benefits include the training and development of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students through participatory research opportunities, thus improving the Nation’s science and technology workforce.

This goal of this research is to develop a novel class of Mo- and W-based bioinspired catalysts for water and wastewater treatment. The specific research objectives are to: (i) introduce Mo and W precursors into rationally designed support materials to achieve high reactivity for the removal of recalcitrant oxyanion pollutants; (ii) investigate reaction mechanisms through detailed material characterization, kinetic studies in variable water matrices, and reaction modeling and validation; and (iii) build engineered flow-through reactors to further evaluate the performance of the new catalysts for practical applications. The bioinspired catalysts use the same metal catalytic elements found in biological enzymes together with electrons from hydrogen gas to carry out the reduction of oxyanions under ambient conditions. Successful completion of this research will generate new knowledge for the development of catalytic reactors that can accommodate novel catalysts for a variety of water and wastewater treatment scenarios. This holds potential to develop new research directions in designing and applying functionalized carbon and silica materials for sustainable water purification. Beyond these research outcomes, the project will support the training and development of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in STEM fields. Their participation in this project will prepare them for careers in industry, academia, or government agencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Palladium (Pd)-based heterogeneous catalysis has been emerging as a promising approach for the treatment and destruction of a range of recalcitrant waterborne pollutants, including toxic oxyanions that are widely detected in surface water, groundwater, and treated water/wastewater across the globe. Specifically, toxic oxyanions can be selectively reduced to innocuous products with the use of H2(g) as a clean hydrogen source, which is activated by Pd. However, low activity for oxyanion reduction has been identified as the bottleneck for practical implementation of catalytic treatment with the use of conventional Pd-based catalysts.

Inspired by the biological oxyanion reduction process, in this project we developed new supported bimetallic catalysts with enhanced reactivity and stability for oxyanion reduction under ambient conditions. The catalysts combined the favorable features of a hydrogenation metal (e.g., Pd, rhodium (Rh)) that activated H2(g) and an earth-abundant promoter metal (e.g., molybdenum (Mo), tungsten (W)) that facilitated oxyanion reduction through the oxygen atom transfer process. The overarching project goal was to advance the development, mechanistic understanding, and application of the supported bimetallic catalysts for oxyanion reduction. This was accomplished via three specific objectives: (1) identify key properties of the bimetallic catalysts with enhanced performance; (2) determine the reactivity, selectivity, and stability of the bimetallic catalysts under various environmental conditions; and (3) elucidate the mechanisms that govern the bimetallic catalysts for oxyanion reduction.

Over the course of this project, we developed two supported bimetallic catalysts, a Rh-WOx and a Pd-MoOx bimetallic catalysts. Compared with single-metal catalysts, the bimetallic catalysts enhanced the catalytic reactivity by 4 to over 55 folds for oxyanion reduction under room temperature and ambient pressure. The bimetallic catalysts also showed high reactivity and stability under a range of water chemistry conditions, and they could be conveniently reused without comprised performance. Through a combination of aqueous kinetics experiments and solid characterization, we observed that the promoter metal species served as a redox shuttle that promoted the overall oxyanion reduction through a proton-assisted process. In addition, we demonstrated the important role of catalyst support in overall catalyst reactivity. Specifically, use of catalyst supports consisting of nitrogen (N)-containing functional groups significantly enhanced the catalyst reactivity for oxyanion reduction. The enhanced catalyst performance was attributed to several mechanisms: (1) the N-containing functional groups promoted the formation of uniformly dispersed fine hydrogenation metal nanoparticles with increased number of reactive sites; (2) the coordination of N-containing functional groups with hydrogenation metal enhanced the activity of reactive metal sites; and (3) the N-containing functional groups locally enriched oxyanions within the catalyst support, thus enhancing the reduction process.

In conclusion, the supported catalysts developed in this project are highly efficient and robust for oxyanion reduction in water. Water contamination with oxyanion pollutants poses severe threats to public health. Results of this project can significantly promote the development and adoption of an effective and sustainable water purification technology to reduce the risk of water contamination with oxyanions, and thus decrease the associated economic and social burden. Specifically, the technology can be employed in a range of environmental applications, such as wastewater treatment and reuse, decentralized or small-scale drinking water treatment, and ex situ remediation of oxyanion-contaminated groundwater. Beyond catalytic oxyanion treatment, knowledge of this project can have broader implications for catalytic treatment of a variety of recalcitrant waterborne pollutants. This project supported the training of two PhD students and several undergraduate researchers for cutting-edge research in water treatment and catalysis technology. Knowledge of this project has also been incorporated into course modules of key undergraduate courses to better prepare students for careers in industry, academic, and government agencies.
